history.content:
EE20 has a good amount of math (complex numbers, time domain, frequency domain, convolution, Fourier transforms), at least compared to EE40. EE40 is more about lab work and doing well on the (tricky and challenging if you don't prepare enough) midterms.

Since you have experience in circuits and actually building them, and have some circuit analysis down, I would recommended EE40 or EE16A.

EE16A does have elements of both 40 and 20, and some which are not included in 20/40. For example, you learn about op-amps which are covered at roughly the same time in the semester as EE40, and there is clearly some math not covered in 40.

Disclaimer: I have finished EE20 already and will be finishing EE40 this semester. I have not taken EE16A and know little about it aside from what you can find on the course website. It would be great if other students could elaborate.

_________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

I would recommend EE40.  I am currently in EE20 and am not enjoying it very much.  EE40 is definitely a lot easier to understand and more relatable.  Not to mention, EE40 is a lot funner.  I don't know much about EE16a.

Oh, and EE40 is typically graded easier than EE20.

EE20 has a good amount of math (complex numbers, time domain, frequency domain, convolution, Fourier transforms), at least compared to EE40. EE40 is more about lab work and doing well on the (tricky and challenging if you don't prepare enough) midterms.

Since you have experience in circuits and actually building them, and have some circuit analysis down, I would recommended EE40 or EE16A.

EE16A does have elements of both 40 and 20, and some which are not included in 20/40. For example, you learn about op-amps which are covered at roughly the same time in the semester as EE40, and there is clearly some math not covered in 40.

children.subject:
OP here.

That 16A is more applicational sounds awesome at first, but I'm still worried about my time commitment.  I'd rather do something slightly less interesting or fun if the lesser workload means I can learn it better or more deeply.

So far It's looking like EE149, EE40, and CSXXX  (maybe databases?)

I think E16A would be better for you because it is designed for freshmen and no knowledge is assumed. We start the semester by going through linear algebra from the very basics. Labs are both hardware and software, mostly on Arduinos, so you're probably comfortable with that. HWs might be a bit more time-consuming than 20 or 40, but they are designed to be more applicational so they should be more interesting. Current EE16A website: http://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~ee16a/sp15/

history.content:
For EE20, EE40, and EE16a

Which has/requires...

  • Biggest time commitment?
  • Most math/calculus used?
  • The fastest fill-up during enrollment?
  • The most difficulty?  (Not the same as time commitment, mind you)

About me:

-It's been a while since I've taken math.  It's now my weakest subject.

-I'm slightly comfortable with basic level circuit analysis, resistence, charge times, etc.

-Very comfortable with transistors, building my own devices, microcontrollers like AVRs, sensors, comparators etc.

I didn't find the catalog descriptions of the courses super helpful, can anyone who has taken the course elaborate on them?

Just trying to figure out of the three classes to take to fill my requirement, but I have 2 other CS courses to take in the fall so I'm trying to keep my schedule to something sane.
history.subject: EE 20/40/16a
